review.title: Revising Incompletely Specified Convex Probabilistic Belief Bases
review.abstract: We propose a method for an agent to revise its incomplete probabilistic beliefs when a new piece of propositional information is observed. In this work, an agent's beliefs are represented by a set of probabilistic formulae -- a belief base. The method involves determining a representative set of 'boundary' probability distributions consistent with the current belief base, revising each of these probability distributions and then translating the revised information into a new belief base. We use a version of Lewis Imaging as the revision operation. The correctness of the approach is proved. The expressivity of the belief bases under consideration are rather restricted, but has some applications. We also discuss methods of belief base revision employing the notion of optimum entropy, and point out some of the benefits and difficulties in those methods. Both the boundary distribution method and the optimum entropy method are reasonable, yet yield different results.

sections.text: Voorbraak (1999) proposed the Partial Probability Theory (PTT), which allows us to partially determine probability assignments, and where there is a distinction between probable information based on (i) hard background information and (ii) some assumptions. He does not explicitly define the "conditional language," but from his examples and discussions one can conclude that he has something like the language LPTT in mind: It contains all the formulas that can be formed with sentences in our Lprob in combination with binding words.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose an approach for generating a new probabilistic belief base from an old one, since there is new, non-probabilistic information in which a belief base is a finite set of sentences, each sentence indicating the probability of a statement about the world. In this context, an agent's belief base represents the set of beliefs that are compatible with the sentences it contains. In this sense, the agent is able to present his knowledge and ignorance of the true state of the world. We used a version of the so-called imaging approach to implement the revision operation. Two methods were proposed: the revision of a finite set of "marginal states of faith" and the revision of a least biased state of faith. We focused on the former and showed that the latter yielded different outcomes. There were two main contributions of this work: The first was to prove that the group of beliefs satisfying Bnew were those that were the original states of faith, the two were the most interesting ones to cover.
